cpystal.color package

Submodules

cpystal.color.color module

color: for dealing with color space.

class cpystal.color.color.Color(color: Union[Tuple[int, int, int], Tuple[float, float, float]], color_system: str, white_point: str = 'D65')[source]

Bases: object

Express color spaces. A part of this class is based on MATLAB and the Python standard module ‘colorsys’.

Note

Thereafter, we use the following type alias without notice:

Color_type := tuple[int,int,int] | tuple[float,float,float].

RGB = Red, Green, Blue

R: [0.0, 1.0], transparent -> red. G: [0.0, 1.0], transparent -> green. B: [0.0, 1.0], transparent -> blue. This RGB is supposed to be linearized.

HSV = Hue(color phase), Saturation(colorfulness), Value(brightness)

H: [0.0, 1.0], red -> yellow -> green -> blue -> magenta -> red. S: [0.0, 1.0], medium -> maximum. V: [0.0, 1.0], black-strong -> black-weak.

HLS = Hue(color phase), Luminance(lightness), Saturation(colorfulness)

H: [0.0, 1.0], red -> yellow -> green -> blue -> magenta -> red. L: [0.0, 1.0], black -> white. S: [0.0, 1.0], medium -> maximum.

YIQ = Y(perceived grey level), I(same-phase), Q(anti-phase)

Y: [0.0, 1.0], black -> white. I: [-0.5959, 0.5959], blue -> orange. Q: [-0.5229, 0.5229], green -> violet.

XYZ

X: [0.0, 0.951] Y: [0.0, 1.0] Z: [0.0, 1.090]

L*a*b*

L*: [0, 100] a*: [-128, 127] b*: [-128, 127]

Note that color_system of the result color of binary operation is always ‘RGB’.

color

Color value.

Type:

Color_type

color_system

Color system (RGB, HSV, HLS, YIQ).

Type:

str

property D50: Color

D50 white point.

Todo

This should be a class property in Python 3.9.

property D65: Color

D65 white point.

Todo

This should be a class property in Python 3.9.

adobergb_to_rgb() → Color[source]

Adobe RGB -> RGB

Note

The value range of (r,g,b) in RGB and Adobe RGB is:

r: [0.0, 1.0] g: [0.0, 1.0] b: [0.0, 1.0]

Returns:

Color expressed in Adobe RGB.

Return type:

(Color)

hls_to_rgb() → Color[source]

HLS -> RGB

Note

The value range of (h,l,s) is:

h: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, 360]) l: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, MAX_LS]) s: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, MAX_LS])

The value range of (r,g,b) is:

r: [0.0, 1.0] g: [0.0, 1.0] b: [0.0, 1.0]

Returns:

Color expressed in RGB.

Return type:

(Color)

hsv_to_rgb() → Color[source]

HSV -> RGB

Note

The value range of (h,s,v) is:

h: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, 360]) s: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, MAX_SV]) v: [0.0, 1.0] (or [0, MAX_SV])

The value range of (r,g,b) is:

r: [0.0, 1.0] g: [0.0, 1.0] b: [0.0, 1.0]

Returns:

Color expressed in RGB.

Return type:

(Color)

lab_to_xyz() → Color[source]

L*a*b* -> XYZ

Note:

The XYZ and RGB color systems basically use the D65 standard light source as the white point, but the L*a*b* color system uses the D50. In order to adjust for this difference, Bradford transformation is used.

The value range of (l,a,b) is:

l: [0.0, 100.0] a: may take an absolute value greater than 100 b: may take an absolute value greater than 100.

D65 white point: (x,y,z) = (0.95046, 1.0, 1.08906) D50 white point: (x,y,z) = (0.9642, 1.0, 0.8249).

Returns:

Color expressed in L*a*b*.

Return type:

(Color)

projection(other_color: Color) → Color[source]

Project the color onto the other color like a mathematical 3D vector.

Parameters:

other_color (Color) – Target of color projection.

Returns:

Projected color. Note that color_system of the returned color is always ‘RGB’.

Return type:

(Color)

to_grayscale() → str[source]
Get the grayscaled color.

The return type is str to conform to the specifications of matplotlib.

Note

The ‘Y’ value in ‘CIE XYZ’ color system is used to convert the color to grayscale.

Returns:

String of float value. The value will be in [0.0, 1.0].

Return type:

(str)

xyz_to_lab() → Color[source]

XYZ -> L*a*b*

Note:

The XYZ and RGB color systems basically use the D65 standard light source as the white point, but the L*a*b* color system uses the D50. In order to adjust for this difference, Bradford transformation is used.

The value range of (l,a,b) is:

l: [0.0, 100.0] a: may take an absolute value greater than 100 b: may take an absolute value greater than 100.

D65 white point: (x,y,z) = (0.95046, 1.0, 1.08906) D50 white point: (x,y,z) = (0.9642, 1.0, 0.8249).

Returns:

Color expressed in L*a*b*.

Return type:

(Color)

class cpystal.color.color.Gradation(start: Color, end: Color, middle: Color | None = None, num: int = 50, next_color_system: str | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

Color gradation

start

Start color of the gradation.

Type:

Color

end

End color of the gradation.

Type:

Color

middle

Middle color of the gradation. Defaults to None.

Type:

Color | None

Examples

>>> ### you can use this class as 'matplotlib.cm' objects.
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> import matplotlib.cm as cm
>>> import numpy as np

>>> R = Color(RED_RGB, RGB)
>>> B = Color(BLUE_RGB, RGB)
>>> Gr = Gradation(R,B)

>>> x = np.linspace(0,2*np.pi,100)
>>> for i in range(30):
>>>     # plt.plot(x,i*np.sin(x), color=cm.hsv(i/30.0))
>>>     plt.plot(x,i*np.sin(x), color=Gr.gradation_linear(i/30).to_rgba())
>>> plt.xlim(0,2*np.pi)
>>> plt.show()
compare_gradations(gradation_list: list[Gradation], rgb_type: str = 'RGB') → None[source]
convert_to_chart(num: int = 50, order: tuple[int, int, int] = (0, 1, 2), next_color_system: str | None = None) → Gradation[source]

Make a list of color gradation like a chart in a color space.

Note

A gradation can be represented as a curve in a color space. Chart lines along with each color axis are used as the gradation curves in this method, assuming that the color space is considered as a real 3D Euclidean space.

Parameters:

num (int) – Length of the return list.

Returns:

Gradation object.

Return type:

(Gradation)

convert_to_helical(num: int = 50, clockwise: bool = True, next_color_system: str | None = None) → None[source]

Make a list of color gradation helically in a color space. This method is mainly used for HSV or HLS.

Note

A gradation can be represented by a curve in a color space. Helical curves are used as the gradation curves in this method, assuming that a cylindrical coordinates system is defined in the color space.

Parameters:

  • num (int) – Length of the return list.

  • clockwise (bool) – If True, direction of spiral winding is clockwise. Defaults to True.

classmethod gradation_helical_list(start: Color, end: Color, middle: Color | None = None, num: int = 50, clockwise: bool = True, next_color_system: str | None = None) → Gradation[source]

Make a list of color gradation helically in a color space. This method is mainly used for HSV or HLS.

Note

A gradation can be represented by a curve in a color space. Helical curves are used as the gradation curves in this method, assuming that a cylindrical coordinates system is defined in the color space.

Parameters:

  • num (int) – Length of the return list.

  • clockwise (bool) – If True, direction of spiral winding is clockwise. Defaults to True.

Returns:

Gradation object.

Return type:

(Gradation)

classmethod gradation_linear_list(start: Color, end: Color, middle: Color | None = None, num: int = 50, next_color_system: str | None = None) → Gradation[source]

Make a list of color gradation linearly in a color space.

Note

A gradation can be represented as a curve in a color space. Straight geodesic lines are used as the gradation curves in this method, assuming that the color space is considered as a real 3D Euclidean space.

Parameters:

num (int) – Length of the return list.

Returns:

Gradation object.

Return type:

(Gradation)
